newsitem.title: USA: TENNIS-WOODFORDE STOPS AGASSI IN INDIANAPOLIS.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-WOODFORDE STOPS AGASSI IN INDIANAPOLIS.

text.p: Australian Mark Woodforde put a halt to the comeback progress of former world number one Andre Agassi with a 6-3 5-7 6-3 defeat in the quarter-finals of the $1 million RCA Championships Friday.

Agassi, determined to recover from a slump which has taken him down to a decade-low ATP Tour ranking of 74th, dropped serve twice in the final set as the 31-year-old from Adelaide claimed the victory in slightly more that two hours.

"Winning the first match was more than I expected, no joke," said Agassi, the 14th seed who will rest and train next week before the August 25 start of the U.S. Open in New York. "The competitiveness and the desire is there.
"I've won three matches this week. I've been looking forward to going out there (on court) now that some good things are happening. I think my game can come around."
The unseeded Woodforde, who reached his first semifinal of 1997, was joined as a winner by the top player left in the field, sixth seed Carlos Moya of Spain, who defeated Czech Jiri Novak 6-3 7-5.

"Woody," one-half of the five-times Wimbledon champion doubles pairing with Todd Woodbridge, will face ninth seed Jonas Bjorkman on Saturday. The Swede beat American qualifier Tommy Ho of the United States 5-7 6-4 7-5.
Bjorkman reached his eighth semifinal of 1997 and boasts a match record since January of 43 wins, 18 defeats.
The Monte Carlo-based player admitted that he might need to consider moving to North America based on his solid results in the United States this year.

"I'm feeling very good, it seems like I like to play over here. I like the hardcourt and I've played some good events here. But I played better in Cincinnati and Montreal. Today, it was just struggling to win."

The 55th-ranked Woodforde, on a comeback roll as well after dropping into the 90s from a slow start to the year, was happy with his showing in the swirling wind which made life difficult on both sides of the net.
"I don't think I'm at the top of my game," said the 31-year-old. "I played well the past week and a half. I've been serving well to get out of tough situations.

"I've played some good tennis this week, but I can get a whole lot better. I know that I can play with most of the guys -- even at my age. There's still lots of room for improvement. It's a great feeling to be in the semis and to beat someone like Andre."

Sweden's 16th seed Magnus Larsson, who knocked out world number one Pete Sampras in the third round, lost a tight final-set tiebreaker to go out to 10th seed Wayne Ferreira of South Africa 3-6 6-3 7-6 (12-10).
Ferreira and Moya play in the second semifinal Saturday.
